title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement package DESCRIPTION. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to mutagen
text: outlines propose change mutagen. detailed discussion contributing packages, please see tidyverse team’s development contributing guide code review principles.

title: Contributing to mutagen
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to mutagen
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed). See tidyverse team’s guide create great issue advice.

title: Contributing to mutagen
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("gvelasq/mutagen", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to mutagen
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to mutagen
text: Please note mutagen project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

title: Getting help with mutagen
text: Thanks using mutagen! filing issue, places explore pieces put together make process smooth possible.

title: Getting help with mutagen
text: Start making minimal reproducible example using reprex package. haven’t heard used reprex , ’re treat! Seriously, reprex make R-question-asking endeavors easier (pretty incredible ROI five ten minutes ’ll take learn ’s ). additional reprex pointers, check Get help! section tidyverse site.

title: Getting help with mutagen
text: Armed reprex, next step figure ask. ’s question: start community.rstudio.com, /StackOverflow. people answer questions. ’s bug: ’re right place, file issue. ’re sure: let community help figure ! problem bug feature request, can easily return report . opening new issue, sure search issues pull requests make sure bug hasn’t reported /already fixed development version. default, search pre-populated :issue :open. can edit qualifiers (e.g. :pr, :closed) needed. example, ’d simply remove :open search issues repo, open closed.

title: Getting help with mutagen
text: efficient possible, development mutagen package tends bursty, shouldn’t worry don’t get immediate response. Typically don’t look repo sufficient quantity issues accumulates, ’s burst intense activity focus efforts. makes development efficient avoids expensive context switching problems, cost taking longer get back . process makes good reprex particularly important might multiple months initial report start working . can’t reproduce bug, can’t fix !

title: Authors and Citation
text: Velásquez G (2025). mutagen: Extensions dplyr's mutate. R package version 0.5.0, https://github.com/gvelasq/mutagen.
code: @Manual{,   title = {mutagen: Extensions to dplyr's mutate},   author = {Gustavo Velásquez},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.5.0},   url = {https://github.com/gvelasq/mutagen}, }

title: Extensions to dplyr's mutate
text: issue human time rather silicon chip time. Human time can wasted taking longer write code, (often much importantly) taking time understand subsequently . – R Inferno (Patrick Burns, 2011) goal mutagen provide extensions dplyr’s mutate(). mutagen provides simple--use functions alternatives complex R idioms variable generation. mutagen functions specific problems encountered R (e.g., working list-columns data frame), others solve generic data science operations inspired excellent set egen (‘extensions generate’) egenmore functions Stata.

title: Extensions to dplyr's mutate
text: can install development version mutagen GitHub :

title: Extensions to dplyr's mutate
text: mutagen functions begin prefix gen_* designed used inside dplyr’s mutate(). mnemonic use mutagen, first mutate generate.

title: Extensions to dplyr's mutate
text: Please note mutagen project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project, agree abide terms.

title: Extensions to dplyr's mutate
text: contributions project gratefully acknowledged using allcontributors package following -contributors specification. Contributions kind welcome!

title: Generate column difference indicator — gen_coldiff
text: function returns binary indicator whether selected columns different.

title: Generate column difference indicator — gen_coldiff
text: data data frame. cols <tidy-select> Columns search across. engine character vector indicating function used test equality. One either "identical" base::identical() ".equal" base::.equal(). ... Arguments passed onto function defined engine. example, tolerance argument can passed onto base::.equal() ignore numeric differences smaller tolerance.

title: Generate column difference indicator — gen_coldiff
text: integer vector value integer 1 (1L) different columns integer 0 (0L) identical (near-equal) columns.

title: Generate column difference indicator — gen_coldiff
code: library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE) a <- tibble(   x = 1:3,   y = as.double(1:3),   z = 1.0001:3.0001 ) gen_coldiff(a, c(x, y)) #> [1] 1 1 1 b <- a %>%   mutate(     q = gen_coldiff(., c(x, y)),     r = gen_coldiff(., c(x, y), engine = "all.equal"),     s = gen_coldiff(., c(x, z), engine = "all.equal", tolerance = 1e-4),     t = gen_coldiff(., c(x, z), engine = "all.equal", tolerance = 1e-5)   ) b #> # A tibble: 3 × 7 #>       x     y     z     q     r     s     t #>   <int> <dbl> <dbl> <int> <int> <int> <int> #> 1     1     1  1.00     1     0     0     1 #> 2     2     2  2.00     1     0     0     1 #> 3     3     3  3.00     1     0     0     1

title: Generate column percent — gen_colpercent
text: function calculates column percent. argument calculates column percents within unique categories grouping columns. prop argument calculates proportion rather percent.

title: Generate column percent — gen_colpercent
text: data data frame. col <tidy-select> single column calculate column percent. optional character vector columns group . prop TRUE, percent shown proportion 0-1 rather percent 0-100. Default FALSE.

title: Generate column percent — gen_colpercent
text: double vector totaling 100 within col. grouping columns specified , percent unique category grouping columns total 100 within col. prop specified, double vector totaling 1 within col (totaling 1 within unique categories grouping columns specified ).

what: Generate list or list-column with NULLs replaced with NAs — gen_listcol_na
title: Generate list or list-column with NULLs replaced with NAs — gen_listcol_na
text: function takes list replaces NULL values NA. useful working list-columns data frame.

title: Generate list or list-column with NULLs replaced with NAs — gen_listcol_na
Generate list or list-column with NULLs replaced with NAs — gen_listcol_na
text: x list list-column modify.

title: Generate list or list-column with NULLs replaced with NAs — gen_listcol_na
text: list NULL values replaced NA.

title: Generate list or list-column with NULLs replaced with NAs — gen_listcol_na
text: Parallelization supported via purrr::in_parallel().

title: Generate list or list-column with NULLs replaced with NAs — gen_listcol_na
code: library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE) a <-   mtcars %>%   select(cyl, vs, am) %>%   slice(1:6) %>%   as_tibble() %>%   mutate(listcol = list(NULL, "b", "c", "d", "e", "f")) glimpse(a) #> Rows: 6 #> Columns: 4 #> $ cyl     <dbl> 6, 6, 4, 6, 8, 6 #> $ vs      <dbl> 0, 0, 1, 1, 0, 1 #> $ am      <dbl> 1, 1, 1, 0, 0, 0 #> $ listcol <list> <NULL>, "b", "c", "d", "e", "f" b <-   a %>%   mutate(across(starts_with("listcol"), gen_listcol_na)) glimpse(b) #> Rows: 6 #> Columns: 4 #> $ cyl     <dbl> 6, 6, 4, 6, 8, 6 #> $ vs      <dbl> 0, 0, 1, 1, 0, 1 #> $ am      <dbl> 1, 1, 1, 0, 0, 0 #> $ listcol <list> NA, "b", "c", "d", "e", "f"

what: Generate rowwise match of all values — gen_rowall
title: Generate rowwise match of all values — gen_rowall
text: function performs rowwise match supplied values across columns data frame. row values equal one supplied values, function returns integer 1 (1L) row, otherwise returns integer 0 (0L).

title: Generate rowwise match of all values — gen_rowall
Generate rowwise match of all values — gen_rowall
text: data data frame. cols <tidy-select> Columns search across. values list values match.

title: Generate rowwise match of all values — gen_rowall
text: binary integer vector indicating whether supplied values matched integer 1 (1L), otherwise returns integer 0 (0L).

title: Generate rowwise match of all values — gen_rowall
text: Parallelization supported via purrr::in_parallel().

title: Generate rowwise match of all values — gen_rowall
code: library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE) a <- tibble(   x = 1:3,   y = rep(NA, 3),   z = letters[1:3],   aa = rep(FALSE, 3) ) val <- list(1, NA, "a", FALSE) val2 <- list(3, NA, "c", FALSE) gen_rowall(a, values = val) #> [1] 1 0 0 b <- a %>%   mutate(     q = gen_rowall(., values = val),     r = gen_rowall(., values = val2)   ) b #> # A tibble: 3 × 6 #>       x y     z     aa        q     r #>   <int> <lgl> <chr> <lgl> <int> <int> #> 1     1 NA    a     FALSE     1     0 #> 2     2 NA    b     FALSE     0     0 #> 3     3 NA    c     FALSE     0     1

title: Generate rowwise match of any values — gen_rowany
code: library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE) a <- tibble(   x = 1:3,   y = rep(NA, 3),   z = letters[1:3],   aa = rep(FALSE, 3) ) val <- list(1, NA, "a", FALSE) val2 <- list(5, NaN, "d", Inf) gen_rowany(a, values = val) #> [1] 1 1 1 b <- a %>%   mutate(     q = gen_rowany(., values = val),     r = gen_rowany(., values = val2)   ) b #> # A tibble: 3 × 6 #>       x y     z     aa        q     r #>   <int> <lgl> <chr> <lgl> <int> <int> #> 1     1 NA    a     FALSE     1     0 #> 2     2 NA    b     FALSE     1     0 #> 3     3 NA    c     FALSE     1     0

what: Generate rowwise count of columns matching a set of values — gen_rowcount
title: Generate rowwise count of columns matching a set of values — gen_rowcount
text: function performs rowwise count columns data frame match set supplied values.

title: Generate rowwise count of columns matching a set of values — gen_rowcount
Generate rowwise count of columns matching a set of values — gen_rowcount
text: data data frame. cols <tidy-select> Columns search across. values list values match.

title: Generate rowwise count of columns matching a set of values — gen_rowcount
text: integer vector number matched values.

title: Generate rowwise count of columns matching a set of values — gen_rowcount
text: Parallelization supported via purrr::in_parallel().

title: Generate rowwise count of columns matching a set of values — gen_rowcount
code: library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE) a <- tibble(   x = 1:3,   y = rep(NA, 3),   z = letters[1:3],   aa = rep(FALSE, 3) ) val <- list(1, NA, "a", FALSE) gen_rowcount(a, values = val) #> [1] 4 2 2 gen_rowcount(a, everything(), values = val) #> [1] 4 2 2 gen_rowcount(a, starts_with(letters[25:26]), values = val) #> [1] 2 1 1 b <- a %>% mutate(q = gen_rowcount(., values = val)) b #> # A tibble: 3 × 5 #>       x y     z     aa        q #>   <int> <lgl> <chr> <lgl> <int> #> 1     1 NA    a     FALSE     4 #> 2     2 NA    b     FALSE     2 #> 3     3 NA    c     FALSE     2

what: Generate rowwise first nonmissing value — gen_rowfirst
title: Generate rowwise first nonmissing value — gen_rowfirst
text: function returns rowwise first nonmissing value data frame.

title: Generate rowwise first nonmissing value — gen_rowfirst
Generate rowwise first nonmissing value — gen_rowfirst
text: data data frame. cols <tidy-select> Columns search across.

title: Generate rowwise first nonmissing value — gen_rowfirst
text: vector rowwise first nonmissing value. vector's type common type rowwise nonmissing values.

title: Generate rowwise first nonmissing value — gen_rowfirst
text: Parallelization supported via purrr::in_parallel().

title: Generate rowwise first nonmissing value — gen_rowfirst
code: library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE) a <- tibble(   x = c(1, NA, 2),   y = c(NA, 3, NA),   z = c(4, NA, 5) ) gen_rowfirst(a) #> [1] 1 3 2 gen_rowfirst(a, all_of(letters[25:26])) #> [1] 4 3 5 b <- a %>% mutate(q = gen_rowfirst(.)) b #> # A tibble: 3 × 4 #>       x     y     z     q #>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1     1    NA     4     1 #> 2    NA     3    NA     3 #> 3     2    NA     5     2 c <-   a %>%   mutate(w = c("a", TRUE, NA), .before = "x") %>%   mutate(q = gen_rowfirst(.)) c # note that q is of type <chr> #> # A tibble: 3 × 5 #>   w         x     y     z q     #>   <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr> #> 1 a         1    NA     4 a     #> 2 TRUE     NA     3    NA TRUE  #> 3 NA        2    NA     5 2

title: Generate rowwise last nonmissing value — gen_rowlast
code: library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE) a <- tibble(   x = c(1, NA, 2),   y = c(NA, 3, NA),   z = c(4, NA, 5) ) gen_rowlast(a) #> [1] 4 3 5 gen_rowlast(a, all_of(letters[24:25])) #> [1] 1 3 2 b <- a %>% mutate(q = gen_rowlast(.)) b #> # A tibble: 3 × 4 #>       x     y     z     q #>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1     1    NA     4     4 #> 2    NA     3    NA     3 #> 3     2    NA     5     5 c <-   a %>%   mutate(aa = c("a", TRUE, NA), .after = "z") %>%   mutate(q = gen_rowlast(.)) c # note that q is of type <chr> #> # A tibble: 3 × 5 #>       x     y     z aa    q     #>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr> <chr> #> 1     1    NA     4 a     a     #> 2    NA     3    NA TRUE  TRUE  #> 3     2    NA     5 NA    5

text: Parallelization supported via purrr::in_parallel().

title: Generate rowwise nth nonmissing value — gen_rownth
code: library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE) a <- tibble(   x = c(1, NA, 2),   y = c(NA, 3, NA),   z = c(4, NA, 5) ) gen_rownth(a, n = 1) #> [1] 1 3 2 gen_rownth(a, n = 2) #> [1]  4 NA  5 gen_rownth(a, all_of(letters[25:26]), n = 1) #> [1] 4 3 5 b <- a %>% mutate(q = gen_rownth(., n = 1), r = gen_rownth(., n = 2)) b #> # A tibble: 3 × 5 #>       x     y     z     q     r #>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1     1    NA     4     1     4 #> 2    NA     3    NA     3    NA #> 3     2    NA     5     2     5 c <-   a %>%   mutate(w = c("a", TRUE, NA), .before = "x") %>%   mutate(q = gen_rownth(., n = 1), r = gen_rownth(., n = 2)) c # note that q and r are of type <chr> #> # A tibble: 3 × 6 #>   w         x     y     z q     r     #>   <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr> <chr> #> 1 a         1    NA     4 a     1     #> 2 TRUE     NA     3    NA TRUE  3     #> 3 NA        2    NA     5 2     5

title: Generate rowwise standard deviation — gen_rowsd
text: function returns rowwise standard deviation data frame.

title: Generate rowwise standard deviation — gen_rowsd
text: data data frame. cols <tidy-select> Columns search across. Non-numeric columns ignored. na.rm Logical vector length one passed onto stats::sd().

title: Generate rowwise standard deviation — gen_rowsd
text: double vector rowwise standard deviation.

title: Generate rowwise standard deviation — gen_rowsd
text: Parallelization supported via purrr::in_parallel(). na.rm TRUE (default), missing values removed. na.rm FALSE, presence NA NaN row return NA row. per documentation stats::sd(), standard deviation length one vector NA.

title: Generate rowwise standard deviation — gen_rowsd
code: library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE) a <- tibble(   x = c(1, NA, 2),   y = c(NA, 3, NA),   z = c(4, NA, 5),   aa = c("a", "b", "c"),   bb = rep(NA, 3),   cc = rep(NaN, 3) ) gen_rowsd(a) #> [1] 2.12132      NA 2.12132 gen_rowsd(a, all_of(letters[25:26])) #> [1] NA NA NA b <- a %>% mutate(q = gen_rowsd(.), r = gen_rowsd(., na.rm = FALSE)) b #> # A tibble: 3 × 8 #>       x     y     z aa    bb       cc     q     r #>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr> <lgl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1     1    NA     4 a     NA      NaN  2.12    NA #> 2    NA     3    NA b     NA      NaN NA       NA #> 3     2    NA     5 c     NA      NaN  2.12    NA

title: Generate rowwise sum — gen_rowsum
text: function returns rowwise sum data frame.

title: Generate rowwise sum — gen_rowsum
text: data data frame. cols <tidy-select> Columns sum. Non-numeric columns ignored. na.rm Logical vector length one passed onto base::sum().

title: Generate rowwise sum — gen_rowsum
text: vector rowwise sum. vector's type common type rowwise numeric values.

title: Generate rowwise sum — gen_rowsum
text: Parallelization supported via purrr::in_parallel(). na.rm TRUE (default), missing values removed. na.rm FALSE, presence NA NaN row return NA NaN row.

title: Generate rowwise sum — gen_rowsum
code: library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE) a <- tibble(   x = c(1, NA, 2),   y = c(NA, 3, NA),   z = c(4, NA, 5),   aa = c("a", "b", "c"),   bb = rep(NA, 3),   cc = rep(NaN, 3) ) gen_rowsum(a) #> [1] 5 3 7 gen_rowsum(a, all_of(letters[25:26])) #> [1] 4 3 5 b <- a %>% mutate(q = gen_rowsum(.), r = gen_rowsum(., na.rm = FALSE)) b #> # A tibble: 3 × 8 #>       x     y     z aa    bb       cc     q     r #>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr> <lgl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1     1    NA     4 a     NA      NaN     5    NA #> 2    NA     3    NA b     NA      NaN     3    NA #> 3     2    NA     5 c     NA      NaN     7    NA

what: mutagen: Extensions to dplyr's mutate — mutagen-package
title: mutagen: Extensions to dplyr's mutate — mutagen-package
text: Extensions dplyr's mutate.

title: mutagen: Extensions to dplyr's mutate — mutagen-package
text: Maintainer: Gustavo Velásquez gvelasq2github@gmail.com

title: mutagen 0.5.0
text: Added gen_coldiff() (#33). Renamed gen_na_listcol() gen_listcol_na() (#32). Renamed gen_percent() gen_colpercent() (#30).

title: mutagen 0.4.0
text: Added gen_rowsd() (#29). Added gen_rowsum() (#28).

title: mutagen 0.3.0
text: Added gen_rownonmiss() (#27). Added gen_rowall() (#26).

title: mutagen 0.2.0
text: Added R-hub v2 workflow (#25). Added egenmore README (#24). Renamed gen_rowmatch() gen_rowany() (#23). Added gen_percent() (#22). Added gen_rowmiss() (#21). Added gen_rowmedian() (#20). Added gen_rowmean() (#19).

title: mutagen 0.1.0
text: Added gen_rowmax() (#18). Added gen_rowmin() (#17). Added gen_rownth() (#16). Added gen_rowlast() (#15). Added gen_rowfirst() (#14). Added gen_rowmatch() (#13). Added gen_rowcount() (#12). Added epigraph README (#10). Added parallelization README (#8, @ivelasq). Added R-universe badge README (#7). Added gen_na_listcol() (#6). Updated usethis helpers usethis 3.1.0 (#5). Added NEWS.md file track changes package (#5).

title: mutagen 0.1.0
text: @thomascwells made first contribution https://github.com/gvelasq/mutagen/issues/4. @ivelasq made first contribution https://github.com/gvelasq/mutagen/pull/3. @delabj made first contribution https://github.com/gvelasq/mutagen/issues/1.
